metadata.description: Information about the Principality of Andorra

chunks.text: Andorra, officially the Principality of Andorra, is a sovereign landlocked country on the Iberian Peninsula, in the eastern Pyrenees in Western Europe, bordered by France to the north and Spain to the south.

Andorra is the sixth-smallest state in Europe, with an area of 468 square kilometres (181 sq mi) and a population of approximately 79,034. The Andorran people are a Romance ethnic group closely related to Catalans.

Andorra is the world's 16th-smallest country by land and 11th-smallest by population. Its capital, Andorra la Vella, is the highest capital city in Europe, at an elevation of 1,023 metres (3,356 feet) above sea level.

The official language is Catalan, but Spanish, Portuguese, and French are also commonly spoken. Andorra is not a member state of the European Union. It has been a member of the Council of Europe and of the United Nations since 1993.

According to tradition, Charlemagne granted a charter to the Andorran people in return for their fighting against the Moors. Andorra was part of the territory ruled by the Count of Urgell and eventually the bishop of the Diocese of Urgell.

In 988, Count Borrell II of Urgell gave the Andorran valleys to the Diocese of Urgell in exchange for land in Cerdanya. Since then, the bishop of Urgell, based in Seu d'Urgell, has been co-prince of Andorra.

The first document that mentions Andorra as a territory is the Acta de Consagració i Dotació de la Catedral de la Seu d'Urgell (Deed of Consecration and Endowment of the Cathedral of La Seu d'Urgell), dated 839.

In 1278, the conflict between the bishop and the count was resolved by the signing of the first paréage, which provided that Andorra's sovereignty be shared between the count of Foix and the bishop of Urgell.

In 1933, France occupied Andorra following social unrest before elections. In 1934, an adventurer named Boris Skossyreff issued a proclamation in Urgell, declaring himself Boris I, King of Andorra, simultaneously declaring war on the Bishop of Urgell.
Andorra's modern constitution was ratified in 1993. The same year, Andorra became a member of the United Nations and the Council of Europe.

Tourism is the mainstay of Andorra's economy, accounting for roughly 80% of GDP. An estimated 8 million tourists visit annually, attracted by Andorra's duty-free status and by its summer and winter resorts.

One of the main sources of income in Andorra is from ski resorts, which total over 175 km of ski grounds. The sport brings in over 7 million visitors annually and an estimated 340 million euros per year.

Andorra is known for its duty-free shopping, with prices for electronics, alcohol, tobacco, and luxury goods being significantly lower than in neighboring countries. This attracts day-trippers from both Spain and France.

In addition to winter sports, Andorra offers hiking, mountain biking, and other outdoor activities in summer. The country's natural beauty and Romanesque churches attract cultural tourists throughout the year.

Andorra consists predominantly of rugged mountains, the highest being the Coma Pedrosa at 2,946 metres. These are dissected by three narrow valleys in a Y shape that combine into one as the main stream, the Gran Valira river, leaves the country for Spain.
Andorra has alpine, continental and oceanic climates, depending on altitude. Its higher elevation means there is, on average, more snow in winter and it is slightly cooler in summer.
Andorra consists of seven parishes: Andorra la Vella, Canillo, Encamp, Escaldes-Engordany, La Massana, Ordino, and Sant Julià de Lòria.

The whole country has been recognised as a single Important Bird Area by BirdLife International, because it is important for forest and mountain birds and supports populations of red-billed choughs, citril finches and rock buntings.

Andorra is home to folk dances like the contrapàs and marratxa, which survive in Sant Julià de Lòria especially. Andorran folk music has similarities to the music of its neighbors, but is especially Catalan in character.
Among the more important festivals and traditions are the Canólich Gathering in May, the Roser d'Ordino in July, the Meritxell Day (National Day of Andorra), and the Andorra la Vella Fair.

Andorran gastronomy is mainly Catalan, although it has also adopted other elements of French and Italian cuisines. Typical dishes include quince all-i-oli, duck with winter pear, roast lamb with nuts, and escudella.

Pre-Romanesque and Romanesque art are one of the most important artistic manifestations of the Principality. There are a total of forty Romanesque churches that stand out as being small austere ornamentation constructions.

The Madriu-Perafita-Claror Valley became Andorra's first UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2004. Summer solstice fire festivals in the Pyrenees was included as UNESCO Intangible cultural heritage in 2015.
